elements.content: The two in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reactions between inorganic complexes bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) offer homometallic and heterometallic 3D novel tetrazole coordination polymers, (3-C5H4N-CN4)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-C5H4N-CN4)Cu(I)Cd(II)Cl2 (2), respectively, in the presence of Lewis acid CuCl2 and CdCl2 in which A is used to replace the organic cyano group and NaN3 during Sharplessʼs tetrazole synthesis. Their interesting luminescent properties are reported.
elements.clean_text: The two in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reactions between inorganic complexes bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) offer homometallic and heterometallic 3D novel tetrazole coordination polymers, (3-C5H4N-CN4)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-C5H4N-CN4)Cu(I)Cd(II)Cl2 (2), respectively, in the presence of Lewis acid CuCl2 and CdCl2 in which A is used to replace the organic cyano group and NaN3 during Sharplessʼs tetrazole synthesis. Their interesting luminescent properties are reported.

elements.content: The two in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reactions between inorganic complexes bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) offer homometallic and heterometallic 3D novel tetrazole coordination polymers, (3-C5H4N-CN4)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-C5H4N-CN4)Cu(I)Cd(II)Cl2 (2), respectively, in the presence of Lewis acid CuCl2 and CdCl2 in which A is used to replace the organic cyano group and NaN3 during Sharplessʼs tetrazole synthesis. Their interesting luminescent properties are reported.
elements.clean_text: The two in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reactions between inorganic complexes bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) offer homometallic and heterometallic 3D novel tetrazole coordination polymers, (3-C5H4N-CN4)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-C5H4N-CN4)Cu(I)Cd(II)Cl2 (2), respectively, in the presence of Lewis acid CuCl2 and CdCl2 in which A is used to replace the organic cyano group and NaN3 during Sharplessʼs tetrazole synthesis. Their interesting luminescent properties are reported.

elements.content: Since pioneering work done by Sharpless et al., there have been tremendous research interests focused on the exploration of in situ tetrazole organic ligand synthesis through 2 + 3 cycloaddition reactions between organic cyano compounds and NaN3 in the presence of Zn2+ ion as Lewis acid catalyst. Actually tetrazole organic ligand synthesis is prepared through the decomposition of Zn-complex (intermediate) under acidic conditions. As a result, there is much research concentrated on the crystallographic characterization of such intermediates containing metal ion (most of them are metal-coordination polymers) and exploration of their applications in nonlinear optical, fluorescent (or phosphorescent), ferroelectric, and chiral properties. Through systematic investigations of the intermediates, it is well realized that the 2 + 3 cycloaddition reaction can occur between organic cyano groups and inorganic sodium azide (NaN3) in the presence of Lewis acid and may extend to the pure inorganic complex 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reaction, that is the inorganic complex with a cyano group is used to replace the pure organic cyano group while azide ion acts as an anion to mimic Shaprlessʼs tetrazole synthesis reaction. An excellent example is the bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) to replace the organic cyano group and inorganic sodium azide in the presence of Lewis acids to complete the above-mentioned pure inorganic cycloaddition reaction to explore new coordination chemistry. The combination of different Lewis acids will lead to the formation of heterometallic coordination polymers (intermediates) never seen before in complexes containing tetrazole. As a continuation of systematic investigations about the trapping, crystallographical characterization, and applications of these intermediates, we perform two pure inorganic complex 2 + 3 cycloaddition reactions, as shown in Scheme . Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of these intermediates with one heterometallic coordination polymer. To the best of our knowledge, the heterometallic tetrazole complex is the first characterized by crystallography.
elements.clean_text: Since pioneering work done by Sharpless et al., there have been tremendous research interests focused on the exploration of in situ tetrazole organic ligand synthesis through 2 + 3 cycloaddition reactions between organic cyano compounds and NaN3 in the presence of Zn2+ ion as Lewis acid catalyst. Actually tetrazole organic ligand synthesis is prepared through the decomposition of Zn-complex (intermediate) under acidic conditions. As a result, there is much research concentrated on the crystallographic characterization of such intermediates containing metal ion (most of them are metal-coordination polymers) and exploration of their applications in nonlinear optical, fluorescent (or phosphorescent), ferroelectric, and chiral properties. Through systematic investigations of the intermediates, it is well realized that the 2 + 3 cycloaddition reaction can occur between organic cyano groups and inorganic sodium azide (NaN3) in the presence of Lewis acid and may extend to the pure inorganic complex 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reaction, that is the inorganic complex with a cyano group is used to replace the pure organic cyano group while azide ion acts as an anion to mimic Shaprlessʼs tetrazole synthesis reaction. An excellent example is the bis(3-cyanopyrdine)copper(II)azide (A) to replace the organic cyano group and inorganic sodium azide in the presence of Lewis acids to complete the above-mentioned pure inorganic cycloaddition reaction to explore new coordination chemistry. The combination of different Lewis acids will lead to the formation of heterometallic coordination polymers (intermediates) never seen before in complexes containing tetrazole. As a continuation of systematic investigations about the trapping, crystallographical characterization, and applications of these intermediates, we perform two pure inorganic complex 2 + 3 cycloaddition reactions, as shown in Scheme . Herein we report the synthesis, crystal structures, and luminescent properties of these intermediates with one heterometallic coordination polymer. To the best of our knowledge, the heterometallic tetrazole complex is the first characterized by crystallography.

elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<graphic id="gs1" orientation="portrait" position="anchor" xlink:href="cg-2007-00528g_0001.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The in situ reactions between complex A and CuCl2 and CdCl2 offer two pale-yellow crystalline coordination polymers, (3-ptz)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-ptz)Cu(I)CdCl2 (2), respectively (3-ptz = 5-(3pyridyl)tetrazolate), in which their IR spectra further confirm the absence of a peak at about 2200 cm−1, suggesting that the cyano group has turned in to the tetrazole group with several typical tetrazolyl group peaks at about 1455, 1456, and 1345 cm−1, respectively. The XPS results further confirm that Cu ion is +1 (see ).
elements.clean_text: The in situ reactions between complex A and CuCl2 and CdCl2 offer two pale-yellow crystalline coordination polymers, (3-ptz)2Cu(I)2 (1) and (3-ptz)Cu(I)CdCl2 (2), respectively (3-ptz = 5-(3pyridyl)tetrazolate), in which their IR spectra further confirm the absence of a peak at about 2200 cm-1, suggesting that the cyano group has turned in to the tetrazole group with several typical tetrazolyl group peaks at about 1455, 1456, and 1345 cm-1, respectively. The XPS results further confirm that Cu ion is +1 (see ).

elements.content: The 3D polymeric structure of 1 was disclosed by an X-ray single crystal diffraction study. There are two crystallographically different Cu(I) centers, while the local coordination geometry around each Cu(I) center in 1 can be best described as a slightly distorted tetrahedron (Figure ). Each Cu(I) center is bonded to four N atoms from four different 3-ptz ligands in which three N atoms are from different tetrazole groups and one is from the pyridyl group. Thus, each 3-ptz ligand adopts a tetradentate bridging spacer to link four Cu centers, while the tetrazole of 3-ptz acts as a μ1−μ3−μ4 bridging mode to result in the formation of a six-membered ring composed of two Cu atoms and four N atoms (Cu1N10N8Cu2N4AN3A). It is interesting to note that there is a 12-membered ring consisting of two Cu centers, six C atoms, and four N atoms (Cu1N9C10C9C1N4Cu2AN5C4C12N10). Three N atoms (N10, N3A, and N2B) bind to the Cu1 center almost equally triangularly, while the one N atom (N9) of the pyridyl ring binds to the Cu(I) center in the slightly distorted long vertex of a tetrahedron. Quite different from that, Cu1 and Cu2 are coordinated by the three N atoms (N5A, N4A, and N8) of two tetrazole groups and one pyridyl group, while one N atom (N6C) of the tetrazole ring binds to the Cu(I) center in the slightly distorted long vertex of a tetrahedron. All the Cu−N [2.033(1), 2.036(2), and 2.068(1) as well as 2.079(3) Å in Cu1 center, and 1.972(1), 2.061(2), and 2.074(1) as well as 2.203(3) Å in Cu2 center] bond distances are normal, while the bond angles around each Cu center range from 97.6(1)° to 112.3.1(1)° in Cu1 and 93.4° to 111.9° in Cu2 and significantly deviate from those expected for an ideal tetrahedron. Due to the tetradentate linking spacer of 3-ptz and larger dihedral angle between the tetrazole and pyridyl rings, the 3D network formed is very complicated. To simplify this network topology, the pyridyl ring can be omitted for clarity. Figure a shows the 2D sheet framework along the c-axis after the pyridyl rings have been omitted; such a sheet exhibits novel three-connected 2D topology ((4;122)(42;6)), Furthermore, if we use a pink ball to represent one tetrazole ligand, the topology of compound 1 can be shown as in Figure b, in which each tetrazole ligand as a tetradentate linker connects four Cu(I) atoms while every copper center coordinates to four tetrazole ligands. Totally, the 3D network in compound 1 is unprecedented topology, to the best of our knowledge.

There are two crystallographically different Cu(I) centers, while the local coordination geometry around each Cu(I) center in 1 can be best described as a slightly distorted tetrahedron (Figure ). Each Cu(I) center is bonded to four N atoms from four different 3-ptz ligands in which three N atoms are from different tetrazole groups and one is from the pyridyl group. Thus, each 3-ptz ligand adopts a tetradentate bridging spacer to link four Cu centers, while the tetrazole of 3-ptz acts as a μ1-μ3-μ4 bridging mode to result in the formation of a six-membered ring composed of two Cu atoms and four N atoms (Cu1N10N8Cu2N4AN3A). It is interesting to note that there is a 12-membered ring consisting of two Cu centers, six C atoms, and four N atoms (Cu1N9C10C9C1N4Cu2AN5C4C12N10). Three N atoms (N10, N3A, and N2B) bind to the Cu1 center almost equally triangularly, while the one N atom (N9) of the pyridyl ring binds to the Cu(I) center in the slightly distorted long vertex of a tetrahedron. Quite different from that, Cu1 and Cu2 are coordinated by the three N atoms (N5A, N4A, and N8) of two tetrazole groups and one pyridyl group, while one N atom (N6C) of the tetrazole ring binds to the Cu(I) center in the slightly distorted long vertex of a tetrahedron. All the Cu-N [2.033(1), 2.036(2), and 2.068(1) as well as 2.079(3) Å in Cu1 center, and 1.972(1), 2.061(2), and 2.074(1) as well as 2.203(3) Å in Cu2 center] bond distances are normal, while the bond angles around each Cu center range from 97.6(1)° to 112.3.1(1)° in Cu1 and 93.4° to 111.9° in Cu2 and significantly deviate from those expected for an ideal tetrahedron. Totally, the 3D network in compound 1 is unprecedented topology, to the best of our knowledge.

elements.content: An asymmetric unit of compound 1 in which each Cu center displays a slightly distorted tetrahedron.
elements.clean_text: 1  An asymmetric unit of compound 1 in which each Cu center displays a slightly distorted tetrahedron.

elements.content: (a) 2D sheet framework perspective view along the c-axis in which the pyridyl ring is omitted for clarity. Color codes: Cu, turquoise, N, blue; C, green. (b) The 3D topological net for compound 1 (Cu(I), turquoise; ligand, pink).
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) 2D sheet framework perspective view along the c-axis in which the pyridyl ring is omitted for clarity. Color codes: Cu, turquoise, N, blue; C, green. (b) The 3D topological net for compound 1 (Cu(I), turquoise; ligand, pink).

elements.content: Quite different from that found in compound 1, there is an additional auxiliary ligand Cl atom in compound 2 acting as two kinds of bridging spacers, one adopting μ3-mode and another μ2-mode to connect two Cd and one Cu center and one Cd and one Cu center, respectively. Probably due to smaller steric hindrance of Cl atom, Cd still likes the adoption of octahedron coordination geometry while Cu still remains in tetrahedral coordination geometry as shown in Figure . Furthermore, the linking mode of 3-ptz adopts μ1−μ2−μ3 mode in the tetrazolate group even though 3-ptz is still a tetradentate linker but is quite different from that of 3-ptz in compound 1. Also it is interesting to note that each octahedral Cd center can be defined as one μ2 Cl atom, two μ3 Cl atoms, and three N atoms from two tetrazolate groups and one pyridyl group, while each tetrahedral Cu center is composed of two N atoms from two tetrazolate groups and two μ3 Cl atoms. Thus, there are three kinds of rings, one four-membered ring (Cd1Acl1Acd1Cl3) and two five-membered ringx (Cd1Cl2Cd1BN2N4 and Cd1N4N5Cu1Cl3).
elements.clean_text: Quite different from that found in compound 1, there is an additional auxiliary ligand Cl atom in compound 2 acting as two kinds of bridging spacers, one adopting μ3-mode and another μ2-mode to connect two Cd and one Cu center and one Cd and one Cu center, respectively. Probably due to smaller steric hindrance of Cl atom, Cd still likes the adoption of octahedron coordination geometry while Cu still remains in tetrahedral coordination geometry as shown in Figure . Furthermore, the linking mode of 3-ptz adopts μ1-μ2-μ3 mode in the tetrazolate group even though 3-ptz is still a tetradentate linker but is quite different from that of 3-ptz in compound 1. Also it is interesting to note that each octahedral Cd center can be defined as one μ2 Cl atom, two μ3 Cl atoms, and three N atoms from two tetrazolate groups and one pyridyl group, while each tetrahedral Cu center is composed of two N atoms from two tetrazolate groups and two μ3 Cl atoms. Thus, there are three kinds of rings, one four-membered ring (Cd1Acl1Acd1Cl3) and two five-membered ringx (Cd1Cl2Cd1BN2N4 and Cd1N4N5Cu1Cl3).

elements.content: An asymmetric unit of compound 2 in which the local coordination geometry around each Cd and Cu center is a slightly distorted octahedron and tetrahedron, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 3  An asymmetric unit of compound 2 in which the local coordination geometry around each Cd and Cu center is a slightly distorted octahedron and tetrahedron, respectively.

elements.content: After all the bridging chloride atoms are omitted, Figure a displays a very interesting 2D sheet, in which Cu atoms and Cd atoms are bridged by the tetrazole ligand into a 3,4-connected V2O5 topological net ((42638)(426)) and the vertex long symbol of (4.4.6)(4.6.4.6.∗.∗); afterward, all of these neighboring 2D sheets are held together by the bridged Cl atoms into the complicated 3D net as shown in Figure b. As a result, compound 2 exhibits the novel five-nodal 3,4,6-connected net ((3;42;52;6)2(32;44;52;65;7;8)24;92)(42;6;93)(43)2).
elements.clean_text: After all the bridging chloride atoms are omitted, Figure a displays a very interesting 2D sheet, in which Cu atoms and Cd atoms are bridged by the tetrazole ligand into a 3,4-connected V2O5 topological net ((42638)(426)) and the vertex long symbol of (4.4.6)(4.6.4.6.∗.∗); afterward, all of these neighboring 2D sheets are held together by the bridged Cl atoms into the complicated 3D net as shown in Figure b. As a result, compound 2 exhibits the novel five-nodal 3,4,6-connected net ((3;42;52;6)2(32;44;52;65;7;8)24;92)(42;6;93)(43)2).

elements.content: (a) 2D sheet framework perspective view along the a-axis in compound 2 in which all Cl atoms are omitted for clarity and (b) 3D regular framework in compound 2, which is formed through Cl atoms connecting neighboring sheets as shown in panel a.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) 2D sheet framework perspective view along the a-axis in compound 2 in which all Cl atoms are omitted for clarity and (b) 3D regular framework in compound 2, which is formed through Cl atoms connecting neighboring sheets as shown in panel a.

elements.content: The solid state luminescent spectra at room temperature were recorded and depicted in Figures , and . In compounds 1 and 2, there are two peaks (at about 490 nm and 520 nm (shoulder) for 1 and at about 492 nm and 520 nm (shoulder) for compound 2) observed. These phenomena are similar to that found in [Cu4Br(dpmp)4] (dpmp = 2-(diphenylmethy1)pyridine), which displays two peaks, one at 480 nm and another 626 nm (shoulder). However, it is worth noting that the shoulder peak in the present cases is the weaker one, while in [Cu4Br(dpmp)4], the shoulder peak is stronger one. On the other hand, maximum emission peaks are quite different from those found in Cu2Br2(2,4′-bpy), [Cu2Br4 (NCXD)(H2O)3] n (NCXD = bis(N,N′- cinchoninium)-p-xylene dibromide), Cu(I)3(4-PYA)2(H2O)(BF4) (4-PYA = 4-pyridylacrylate), and [Cu(I)(4-PYA)(PPh3)](n), which all display a maximum emission peak at about 580 nm. Due to the heterometallic Cd and Cl in the framework of compound 2, the peak at 490 nm becomes much sharper than that of compound 1. It is emphasized that the heterometallic Cu(I)−Cd−Cl luminescent coordination polymer is unprecedented even though the detailed photoluminescent mechanism is not clear in the present status. However, probably because the solid state structure in compound 2 is much more rigid than that of 1, the resulting shoulder peak is significantly sharper than that in 1. This can be explained by conformational rigidity, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π−π*) excited state.
elements.clean_text: The solid state luminescent spectra at room temperature were recorded and depicted in Figures , and . In compounds 1 and 2, there are two peaks (at about 490 nm and 520 nm (shoulder) for 1 and at about 492 nm and 520 nm (shoulder) for compound 2) observed. These phenomena are similar to that found in [Cu4Br(dpmp)4] (dpmp = 2-(diphenylmethy1)pyridine), which displays two peaks, one at 480 nm and another 626 nm (shoulder). However, it is worth noting that the shoulder peak in the present cases is the weaker one, while in [Cu4Br(dpmp)4], the shoulder peak is stronger one. On the other hand, maximum emission peaks are quite different from those found in Cu2Br2(2,4'-bpy), [Cu2Br4 (NCXD)(H2O)3] n  (NCXD = bis(N,N'- cinchoninium)-p-xylene dibromide), Cu(I)3(4-PYA)2(H2O)(BF4) (4-PYA = 4-pyridylacrylate), and [Cu(I)(4-PYA)(PPh3)](n), which all display a maximum emission peak at about 580 nm. Due to the heterometallic Cd and Cl in the framework of compound 2, the peak at 490 nm becomes much sharper than that of compound 1. It is emphasized that the heterometallic Cu(I)-Cd-Cl luminescent coordination polymer is unprecedented even though the detailed photoluminescent mechanism is not clear in the present status. However, probably because the solid state structure in compound 2 is much more rigid than that of 1, the resulting shoulder peak is significantly sharper than that in 1. This can be explained by conformational rigidity, thereby reducing the nonradiative decay of the intraligand (π-π*) excited state.

elements.content: The solid state photoluminescent spectrum of compound 2 at room temperature.

elements.content: In conclusion, a new in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reaction between inorganic complexes in the presence of Lewis acid yields novel homo- and heterometallic coordination polymers (as intermediates). This will open up the routine to the synthesis of novel luminescent tetrazole coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, a new in situ 2 + 3 intermolecular cycloaddition reaction between inorganic complexes in the presence of Lewis acid yields novel homo- and heterometallic coordination polymers (as intermediates). This will open up the routine to the synthesis of novel luminescent tetrazole coordination polymers.

elements.content:
X-ray data in CIF format and additional figures showing the XPS results. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

The preparation of compound 1: A is obtained through mixing Cu(N3)2 in water and 3-cyano-pyridine in methanol with ratio 1:2. The hydrothermal treatment of A in the presence of CuCl2 (1 mmol) at 140 °C for 2−3 days offers pale-yellow compound 1 (0.15 mmol, 0.062 g, yield 15% based on A). Anal. Calcd for C12H8Cu2N10 (1): C, 34.34; H, 1.91; N, 33.35. Found: C, 34.42; H, 1.86; N, 33.42. IR: 3428(m), 3056(m), 2361(w), 2182(w), 1890(w), 1634(w), 1605(m), 1579(m), 1451(vs), 1420(vs), 1360(m), 1322(m), 1200(w), 1146(m), 1129(m), 1033(m), 997(m), 957(m), 819(vs), 755(s), 708(Vs), 637(w), 455(w).

The preparation of compound 2: The hydrothermal treatment of A in the presence of CdCl2 (1 mmol) at 140 °C for 2-3 days offers pale-yellow compound 2 (0.20 mmol, yield 33%). Anal. IR: 3407(w), 3076(w), 2355(m), 1779(w), 1661(w), 1644(w), 1644(w), 1609(s), 1582(s), 1452(s), 1419(vs), 1373(vs), 1349(m), 1331(w), 1235(w), 1207(w), 1142(m), 1120(m), 1066(w), 1017(s), 936(w), 817(vs), 702(vs), 641(m), 563(w).

metadata.title: Heterometallic Tetrazole Coordination Polymer Formed through 2 + 3 Cycloaddition Reaction between Inorganic Complexes in the Presence of Lewis Acid
